title: The Earth's Water Cycle
summary: From clouds to puddles and back again, water is always on the move around our planet.
imageAlt: Stylized diagram of clouds, rainfall, and water looping through the cycle.
author: Jacob Sutanto
body: Have you ever wondered where a raindrop travels? The water cycle is a pattern that moves water on, above, and below Earth.
The sun warms lakes and oceans, turning water into vapor. This step is called evaporation.
The vapor floats up and cools. Tiny droplets form clouds in a step named condensation.
When clouds grow heavy, water falls as rain, snow, or hail. This is precipitation.
Some water runs into rivers. Some sinks underground to feed plants. Eventually it returns to lakes or oceans, and the cycle starts again.

questions.prompt: What is the very first step in the water cycle described in the passage?
questions.explanation: The sun warms water so it rises as vapor in the step called evaporation.

questions.prompt: When water vapor cools and forms droplets, the step is called __________.
questions.explanation: Condensation creates clouds from cooled vapor droplets.

options: Water falls to Earth as rain, snow, or hail.
Water turns into gas and floats away.
questions.explanation: Precipitation is when heavy clouds release water back to Earth.

questions.prompt: Match each word to the correct water cycle description.

answer.c: Water falls as rain, snow, or hail
answer.d: Water gathers in rivers, soil, or oceans

questions.explanation: Each stage keeps water moving in a repeating loop.

questions.prompt: Arrange these steps in the order they appear in the passage.
sequence: Water vapor cools and forms clouds
Clouds release rain, snow, or hail
Water returns to rivers or underground
questions.explanation: The text follows water from evaporation to condensation, precipitation, and collection.

questions.prompt: After it rains, some water sinks underground to feed ______.
questions.explanation: Rain can soak into soil to help plants grow.

questions.prompt: Which best explains why the water cycle is called a cycle?
options: It repeats the same pattern over and over again.
It only happens one time each spring.
It stops working whenever the sun sets.
questions.explanation: Water keeps moving through the same stages in a continuous loop.

questions.prompt: Describe two ways water moves after precipitation falls.
acceptableAnswers: Some water runs into rivers and some sinks into the ground to feed plants.
It can flow to rivers or soak underground where plants use it.
questions.explanation: The passage lists rivers and underground pathways after rain.

questions.prompt: Which natural energy source powers evaporation?
questions.explanation: Sunlight provides the heat needed for evaporation.

questions.prompt: What would happen if water never returned to lakes or oceans?
options: The water cycle would stop and Earth would lose fresh water.
There would be extra clouds every day.
Nothing would change about the cycle.
questions.explanation: Water has to collect again so the sun can heat it and keep the cycle moving.

prompts: Draw the path of a raindrop through the water cycle.
How does the water cycle help living things?
